text: the forlorn and desperate trek continues
to some kind of safety some of the
thousands of members of Iraq's Yazidi
minority fleeing the advance and the
brutality of the Sunni militant fighters
now known as the Islamic state I had to
walk halfway here alone I have three
children
this one is with me but I have lost the
others I haven't seen them all my
husband walking just we have the bottle
of water sometimes they get more US air
drops of vital supplies to desperate azd
still trapped and exposed on Mount
Sinjar in northern Iraq this
humanitarian crisis has refocused
international concern on the threat
posed by the Sunni militants in Iraq and
beyond with the help of US airstrikes
Kurdish forces have retaken some ground
from the militants in the north but as
the militants celebrate and parade their
successes in their own videos word that
they've also made a new advance further
south closer to the Iraqi capital
Baghdad and heightened security on the
streets of the capital but this it seems
is because of the heightened political
crisis among the countries divided
leadership shock Waris me as he
struggles to keep his job the Shiite
Prime Minister Nuri al-maliki went on
national television overnight saying he
was taking the country's President to
court and a show of support on the
streets but amid confused and
contradictory reports from the capital
the country's political turmoil seemed
set to deepen all this will dismay the
Americans and others who also see the
prime minister as a block to creating an
Iraqi unity government one thing all
Iraqis need to know that there will be
little international support of any kind
whatsoever for anything that deviates
from the legitimate constitutional
process that is in place and being
worked on now
in northern Iraq this camp offers a
place of relative sanctuary for some
there's no end in sight to the crisis
Nick Child's BBC news
